chapter.title: Design Overview
chapter.para: There are two parts to the &THIS.EXAMPLE; example.
The first part is the JMX Bean to be deployed in a JBoss AS5 instance. Within this context, the Java EE application will be used to fire JAIN SLEE events to the JAIN SLEE container
The second part is the JAIN SLEE application to be deployed in the JAIN SLEE container, which will handle the events fired, printing information about it in the container's console.

section.title: Design Overview: SLEE Service
section.para: JAIN SLEE service is simplest of all. It performs very basic actions when handling each received event:

listitem.para: The Slee service detaches from the activity where the event was fired. This lets the container end the event as it becomes unreferenced.
The Slee service logs the message contained in the event. The message will then become visible in the container's console.

section.title: Design Overview: JMX Bean
section.para: JMX Client fires events into JAIN SLEE container, using the standard SLEEConnection API.
There are two possible scenarios of client and server deployment:

listitem.para: JMX Bean and JAIN SLEE run in the same JVM. In this case both parts are deployed in same JBoss AS, and no additional tools are needed.
In this case JMX Client and JSLEE container run in different JVMs. The &THIS.PLATFORM; JAIN SLEE Remote SLEE Connection Tool, which uses JCA, must be deployed in the Java EE container.
